column9: Started taking this med because i was going thru a divorce and custody battle and was extremely upset all the time and waking up during the night with anxiety. I was afraid to take it because didn't want any side effects from it so put off taking it. Then one day was very upset so I decided I had to try something. I was prescribed 0.25mg. the first time i split that in half and it did nothing so the next day I took a whole one and it took the edge off with no side effects except for some yawning and a little bit sleepy but not bad. Only took one (.025mgs)during the day  even though it says may be used up to 3xs a day but one took the edge off. As far as needing more I dont take it everyday . My doctors said I can take two .025mg tabs at once making it a total of 0.5mg to help more when i need it--which is still only half a One mg tab. This seems to help alot when i do need it without making me feel loopy or foggy a little sleepy but its not like i have to go lay down to sleep (i only take during the day when needed)I do notice however that the next morning i feel a little nauseous if i took it the day before. Try it and see if it works for you if it doesn't try something else .Use it in moderation and only when needed to reduce the need for dependency. Good luck

column9: Clonazepam wasn't working that well for my anxiety so my doctor switched me to Xanax.  It helps for my anxiety and panic attacks. If I have to take it at work I get painfully tired and can barely keep up with what I need to do.  I have insomnia and it will help calm me down at night enough to sleep but if I know there are things that I need to do that I need to be alert for I am hesitant to take it.  I just wish there was something that would help without putting me to sleep.  The only thing I can do is make sure I have enough caffeine to keep me awake but I go through withdrawals if I don't keep up with the caffeine.  It is a vicious cycle and it isn't helping my anxiety.  I lost my insurance so I can't go back to the doctor to get a new med for my anxiety so I just have to stick with this method until I can figure something else out.  Side effects suck!

column9: Iaking xanax off and on for several years. At firt my anxiety was not that bad. (The dr.s believed I developed the anxiety after a spinal tab went wrong and I was in the hosp.for 10 days and needed surgery.) At first it was .05 mg 3 x a day, than up to 1  mg 3x a day and that seemed to work and work well for me. Then once I STOPPED on my own and I called my Dr. who at that point I was off the xanax for 5 full days and did not have any side effects. He was not happy that I stopped on my own but understood. 4 full months go by and I seemed fine until One afternoon and I had to stop at the market and while shopping I had a sereve Anxiety attack. I had to leave my shopping cart and leave. I HAD to get out of there asap. So I went back to my dr. and told him. When my ANXIETY came back,it came back worse than before. I now I'am on xanax 2 mg 3x a day as needed but I only take as needed and my Dr. know's this. My Dr. this time wrote for 2 mg 3 x a day for a total of 90 pills a month. Plus he wrote for a refill of up to 4 times within the next 6 month's which I did not even know this medication could be a refill. I thought you had to see a Dr. every time you needed a script. I Do like this medication, it does help but sometime's it makes me tired.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years
column9: When i first took xanax i took two, two mg xanax and i slept for 3 days strait.  As time progressed i loved it so much,  then i started upping my dosage because 4mg's per day wasnt enough, so i started taking more, it got so bad that i had to have at least 8 bars a day, thats 16mg's. Finally wen i slept through 6 months of my life, and gained 20 pounds, i wanted to stop.  This was a challenge.  I felt like my heart was going to explode and i didnt eat anything, obviously i was going through withdraws.  The racing of the heart was unbearable.  Thank god we live in the information age so i looked up withdrawls from xanax.  And i discovered that you cant just stop taking the pills, you have to cut your doses in half based on a chart.  After that was all over with i feel much better, i never had any anxiety problems i was just having fun, bud damn it cost me 6 months of my life.  I lost alot of weight and now i feel awsome. Just stick to the pills once in a while. BE SAFE< PLAY SAFE< STAY SAFE besides even if you have anxiety boo hoo its all psychological!! So dont be a baby and face your fears!!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have suffered from severe panic disorder for most of my adult life also associated with agoraphobia. I also have difficulty sleeping. I take 1mg in the AM and 2mg at bedtime. I still get breakthrough panic attacks and floating anxiety but not as frequent. When i do I have extra Xanax to take for these breakthroughs. i have noticed over the past few months that I am not sleeping more than 4 hours a night so my physician added 50 mg of trazadone to take with my xanax at night. I still wake up several times and noticed as of late that I get severe cramping in my legs (charlie horses} which may be due to the Trazadone. I will discuss this with my doctor at my next visit. column2: renae1221, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've taken Xanax for at least four years and it has done wonders for my panic attacks. I was diagnosed with GAD (general anxiety disorder) and there were times where I was convinced I was close to death; this medication helps when the symptoms pop up. Yes, it can be addictive, but if you suffer from severe anxiety as I do, you'll find that it's a non issue. I do have to stress that it's important to take something with it (I use to take Prozac, now, I'm on Paxil). Xanax helps to taper off the anxiousness, the anti-depressant treats my GAD long term. I'm finally at a point where I've been able to reduce my dosage due to Paxil and only take the benozpine as needed.It really does work wonders. My best advice is to take it when you're not working or driving (this way you can know how it affects you). Also, don't take more then the prescribed dosage. Should you find that it's not helping, talk to your doctor immediately about changing the dosage to find a level that works for you. When you feel ready to get off the drug, don't just stop, gradually decrease your consumption or lower your dosage. I use to think I was just crazy or overly paranoid, I now realize that I'm not, what I have is a chemical disorder--this medication works and helps me to maintain a right balance.

column2: twospeed,  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year
coyote3558, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have bipolar disorder, ADHD, generalized anxiety, agoraphobia, panic disorder and a substance abuse history.  I'm afraid of the freeway, which I had to drive on 60 miles a week to get to the hospital for my husband's cancer treatment. It was a nightmare  I'm also phobic of malls, large stores, DMV, medical offices, traffic, supermarkets, etc, etc. I won't to leave my "safe zone", the community I live in, without a very, very compelling reason.  The panic I feel restricts my ability to travel or go to places I'd like to see that are out of town, even to visit family.  I can force myself to leave the house with great effort, breaking down the activity into "baby steps", but it's difficult, scary and embarassing.  My  problem with a substance abuse history interferes with getting treatment for my anxiety, ADHD and insomsia.  I was so happy when my doctor perscribed Xanax as I'd heard it was very effective for agoraphobia and panic.  To my horror, I found out I can't use it. I used it as perscribed for 3 months.  I don't even remember when I started to overuse it, but I lost 3 days to a weird amnesia, like an alcohol blackout, but worse.  I was almost arrested, ran my car into a fence, went to work inebriated, screamed at my husband and then remembered only bits and pieces later.  I was so disoriented that I didn't even realize that I'd had memory loss for several days sfter the fact.  I understand that this medication is very helpful for many people, but I DO NOT recommend it for people with substance abuse tendencies.  Beware pill heads, recovered or not!  This drug doesn't even let you remember any fun you might have had on it.

column2: renae1221, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I know there are people who state this drug is highly addictive; however, when taken accordingly, it can do wonders to alleviate anxiety. I take Xanax and Paxil (both are important for me as I have been diagnosed with General Anxiety Disorder). I use to go to sleep with my cell phone and insurance cards beside me, convinced I was going to have a heart attack. My heart would race, I'd grind my teeth, and my thoughts were racing a thousand miles a minutes. With this medication, I no longer have these symptoms.In the few moments I do feel anxious or my breaths are shallow, I simply take one pill, and within the time the symptoms abate. I would say that the Paxil is the key, but for someone like me, who is plagued with anxiety attacks without provocation the Xanax has been instrumental in alleviating the attacks. Talk to your doctor about it, ONLY take what you're prescribed, and over time you may find yourself not having to take the Xanax nearly as much. In the three plus years I've been on, I only take it when I need it now (instead of daily).

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Xanax is a very effective medication for TEMPORARY anxiety.  It is not useful as a maintenance medication.  It should only be used on an as needed basis.  For one, your body becomes tolerant to the medication when taken regularly, and you also become dependent.  It should be taken very judiciously.

column2: butterfly33, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Xanax is a mixed bag.  On one hand it is  lifesaver, on the other hand it is a nasty little pill to be avoided like the plague. I've been on it about 15 years and take it everyday, I have never, not a single day, been without it. I get 90 bars a month and it is up to me to regulate my dosage. Some days I only need a bar, somedays I need 4 bars. I am in no way a drug addict, I don't even drink (at all). Withdrawal is REAL and MISERABLE.  Sometimes at night I'll wake up covered in sweat with full on tremors.  I keep water and a tiny pill box of xanax on my night stand. The good is I can live a calm, active, normal life that I simply could not have otherwise. Over the years I have had my bottle of xanax stolen several times.  Hide it when you get it. People will take it out of the medicine cabinet, leaving you in a perilous situation- luckily my Dr. has always trusted me and refilled early.  But, really, hide them. Use them as directed or you will be in a world of hurt- HURT-. Xanax addiction is very dangerous.

column2: Katrina, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I took Xanax for almost six years to treat panic disorder. I typically took .25-.50mg a day and funtioned pretty well at this dose. I was still having problems with depression, though, and went to see a psychiatrist who upped my dosage to 1mg. I thought I had hit the Xanax lottery! Unfortunately, with my history of alcoholism, this proved to be very dangerous. I almost died this summer when I mixed the Xanax with vodka and diphenhydramine (Benadryl). I had to be hospitalized for 4 days and under 24 hour care to be weened off this drug. Since stopping it, I have found that I actually have LESS anxiety then when I was on it. After a while, you start to have a roller coaster effect with your anxiety levels getting higher and higher without the drug in your system, so you take more to knock down the anxiety. I think more clearly than I have in years since I stopped taking it,and I no longer suffer severe blackouts and dangerous loss of inhibition when I drink. Be very careful with this drug if you are a drinker. It's not worth losing your life over.

column2: Kkbdal, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've had sleep issues all my life and was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia at the age of 16. Not long after severe anxiety and panic attacks came along. Then a sereve car crash brought on PTSD. I just thank God my Dr had already put me on Xanax for my sleep issues when all this other crap happened in my life. It has helped me from going off the deep end several times! My dosage is 1 three times a day as needed but I only take them when I really need them. Like others have said they can be addictive and once I almost slipped when things in my life got really really bad. But whats the point in drugging yourself into a stupor and acting like an idiot when you have problems to solve!! I am 33 now and have been on and off the drug since I was 16 and yes it does taste nasty as all get out but it does its job. It calms you, for me it stops my racing thoughts so I can sleep restfully with no panic attacks in my sleep. But one thing I have learned and this may sound silly, but something that powerful, you have to respect it. Because if you don't it will end up taking over life and destroy everything you have. I know b/c it happened to my bestfriend despite everything I did to try and stop her. So friends stay safe and stay healthy!! And may love always be in your hearts!

column2: rockione, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more
column9: I had viral encephalitis at age 33.  I almost lost my life.  Most of my sleep centers weredestroyed or damaged.  Sleep would NOT come. I went to Mayo's for Sleep Study.  Dr. Peter Hauri, widely known for his work,did my study.  He remarked "you need to find a regimen that works for you".  I was told to take Carbo/levo (generic for the drug people take for Parkinson's), Alprazolam 1 mg 2xdaily, and the generic for remeron (sleeping pill).  I have had a couple of changes on the sleeping pill and I need to get off after 60 days and take Benadryl so as not to habituate. If I stay on this regimen, I do very well in my life.  I'm very active in church,I have sang all my life, am currently a Sweet Adeline.  I travel, attend outings with friends and drive a car.  I NEVER feel drugged, but if I forget meds, I pay a very high price with a panic attack that lasts until I get to my meds.  Yes, you could say I am addicted, but I want to live a normal life and this regimen helps me do that.  I am retired, but held a part time job for almost 15 years.  That is normal living.  Maybe I am locked into this regimen, but I am an active person. I am always monitored by my physician.  If people want to put me in a category that is not pleasing to everyone, that's ok.  I need this regimen to be active.  I am on these meds because they work.  They work and I am free to work or play.  I do volunteer work at the nursing  homes in my area.  If I didn't go to visit these people, they wouldn't have anyone else who would see them.  I like my full life and don't intend to give it up over a silly stigma.  People, these meds work. Get over yourself and get busy!!

column2: PanicFree, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I would begin by stating I believe in this drug and how it works with individuals that really need it, I have been on and off of it for 4 years.  I do not take more than one to two times a day and a max of 1mg and never take your doses on a regular 4 hour schedule.  This is how I have kept from becoming addicted, as advised by my doctor.  It has worked.  Now with saying all of that I then have to add that one of my best friends was also on this medication and she became addicted and when it was no longer enough she turned to pain meds and she is now a true pill popping addict.  So be very cautious and listen to your body.  I have severe panic attacks so I do understand when others state they have to have it to function.  I say to that look at your schedule and think about when the best time of the day maybe when you are alone that you can skip doses so that you never become addicted.  It is a horrible double edge sword; a beautiful thing when taken correctly and satan himself when abused.

column2: magickalstone, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed Xanas for chronic sleeping problems along with anxiety, and panic attacks.  It has been a miracle drug for me.  I have a wonderful doctor who first put me on Lexapro.  The Lexapro worked for the panic attacks and anxiety, but the side effects were terrible.  So then he switched me to Xanax a year ago, and my whole life changed.  I take .5mg 3xday, but basically just take it as needed.  No side effects and it works very quickly.  I do agree that there is a stigma about this medication, but people need to realize that patients are prescribed this for a reason.  I also suffer from extreme spinal stenosis, and it relaxed the muscles in my back that start to spasm because of the intense pain of the stenosis.  It helps me sleep through the night without being a zombie the next morning.  Xanax is truly a wonderful drug and a god send to me.  Don't be afraid to be proactive in your health care.  If you think this medication may help you than you need to talk to your doctor about it.  After all you are the customer and you are paying him, so he should take your comments and desires into consideration.  I hope that people find this useful.

column2: Hooray for Xanax, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After a big move (losing my home) I went into severe panic attacks and could not sleep or focus. I literally felt like someone opened up my head and sprinkled pepper on my brain. As soon as I would finally fall aslee due to sheer exhaustion, I would wake up 10 minutes later with severe anxiety.I was hesitant to try medication because I've always been able to get through difficult situations through through breathing exercises but I had not slept in weeks. It was so awful to be awakened 10 times a night.Finally my doctor prescribed .5 mg of Xanax three times a day. What's great is that when I took the first pill, it worked right away. I got a little sleepy about 15 minutes after taking it but then I was back to my normal old self. I didn't feel drugged, I just felt like I could handle things again. I still have the same yucky situation and when it starts to overwhelm me, I take my little peach-colored pill and then I feel like life is going to be okay, no matter what happens, I have the tools to try to move forward and all is not lost.I wish anyone with anxiety the best with your trouble. I hope me sharing my experience helps.  PS...My doctor also prescribed Lunesta which works great for sleeping the night through (but you must definitely make sure you will be able to stay IN BED for at least 7 hours or you will be loopy when you get up, and could make stupid mistakes like leaving the front door open, etc.)The nice thing that since I've been on Xanax, I don't need the Lunesta to sleep. Good luck everyone...don't despair. Things will get better!

column2: Xanax man 061, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Works very quickly to treat anxiety and panic attacks. Be very cautious, it is extremely addictive. Meaning, if you take high doages (3-6 mg daily) over several weeks then suddenly stop, you may get seizures from withdrawals,exremely dangerous to stop abruptly. The secret is to cut down very gradually by .25 or .5  mg daily until you get to 1mg daily dose. Then you can reduce by .25 mg after 1 week at 1 mg until you get off it. I actually cut the tablets down to 1/8 mg pieces and reduced that way very effectively. Best not ever to go above 1mg daily. It is a very deceptive drug, stores up in your inetrnal organs. I have been taking it for over 5 years. I now know how to handle it. At one point I was taking 6 mg a day for several months. Took Months to reduce down to 1mg a day!

column2: brneyezz, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Xanax for 6 yrs. when I had my very first anxiety attack after my 1st separation from my ex-husband; I have never been addicted to it and only take it when an attack occurs.  Unlike what I have read and heard, I do not feel this drug is habit-forming, in my opinion.  The only affect I get from taking this medication is my anxiety attack is relieved within 10-15 minutes and I rarely need to take a second pill unless the attack occurs again.  I have on a scale from 1-10 a 8-9 in my attack range.  My 2mg. dose does the trick every time.  I keep 2 on me at all times because I never know when an attack will occur.  I have no euphoric feeling, which I like, and only get relief from the attack which the drug was made to do.  I can keep a full prescription bottle for months at a time and my doctor knows I only take this medication when needed.  My 18 yr. old daughter was recently prescribed this after coming off heavy meth use and loves it, she too only uses it when needed and agrees it is not habit forming.  I administer her daily dose and find she rarely uses it, unless she feels the affects of anxiety which can occur from detoxing off meth or other hard core drug use that she has been sober from for almost a month.  Xanax was administered to her for 3 days 1 very 6-8 hours and was fully detoxed within 4 days, thereafter she has rarely taken her Xanax because she states she only needs it when she feels that anxious feeling to use or deal with the affects of her anxiety.  By using it ONLY when you feel anxiety is what I recommend and so should your doctor; if you find you are using more than what is prescribed I would suggest talking to your doctor and finding out what may be underlying a more serious condition that may not be anxiety but a more serious condition like drug abuse, or the need to feel medicated to cope with reality.  That is my opinion because I have seen too much drug abuse in my family and have learned what is real and what is not.

column2: AmyC, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had severe panic attacks for about 10 years.  I've tried everything there is and xanax DO work for anxiety attacks, the only problem is they don't stay in your system long enough to "calm" you if you're anxious pretty much 24/7.  That's where the abuse comes in because you have to take so many.  Also, I've seen waaaay too many people abusing this drug that don't even have anxiety!  That's why Dr.'s  will hardly prescribe it to people.   I now take Klonopin 3 times a day religiously and it works just as well as long as you take the dosage even if you aren't anxious.  My Dr. does give me a few xanax a month for "breakthrough" anxiety attacks because they work so fast.  So, I have finally found the perfect combination to make me feel human again!!  Good Luck and maybe you could try this as well.

column9: I am on 4 to 5 2mg's a day for Panic,Anxiety and PTSD.I was looking up the maximum dosage and it appears that I'm at it.10mg's a day.As long as I get Greenstone(owned by Pfizer who makes name brand Xanax)I do okay.I am also on 2 30mg Restoril(hs)(another Benzodiazapine)and 2 100mg's of Serequel at bedtime(hs).I do get drowsy in the daytime because I'm also on 80mg's of Methadone,for pain,I take when I wake up.I don't take Xanax near my Methadone so now I'm on Nuvigil 250mg's a day.All of it seems to work as long as I take it as prescribed.I have been informed of the danger of Xanax and Methadone and I take it seriously.I actually think Soma is one of the deadliest drugs out there.I'm almost 37 and hope to get off most meds in the future.

column2: cherie-boo, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: My Dr. put me on Xanax, when my husband died, young! It was unexpected, and a sudden death. He put me on 6mgs/day. Later, he dropped my dosage to 4mgs. Sometimes: 2mg in the morning and 2mg at night.  Since, it helps me sleep sounder.  I know that I have an addiction to it, since the length of time, I have been on it.  My memory has worsened, and I know it is the xanax that is doing the damage. I advise anyone thinking of getting on this drug, to read up on it. column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I tried taking ecstasy once and I had a bad reaction to it. Ever since I took it Ive developed horrible anxiety towards pills so it was extremely hard for me to find something to make my panic disorder go away. Xanax was the only thing that helped me. I dont believe in anti depressants but I couldnt leave my house without having a panic attack so I tried Celexa, Buspar, and Pamelor. None of them worked because the effects they had on my brain triggered my anxiety. Xanax did not give me that fear. I took it as needed for a year until I gradually travelled further from my house without taking any. I went back to my therapist, took up yoga and quit smoking. Now I rarely take xanax unless it's for situations to accommodate my new claustrophobia such as planes and small rooms. Xanax is not addicting, it just works. The problem is that your body gets used to the lower doses and you have to slowly increase your dose to be able to cushion the anxiety. I started at .5 and cut them in half and now Im at a comfortable 1mg. Im writing this review because xanax was the only thing that helped me fix a stupid mistake I should never have done in the first place. Good luck with your anxiety. I highly recommend any kind of change in your life to help put you in the right direction towards recovery. Please do not start taking xanax unless you have intent to manage on your own, the fear of being without xanax should not replace your original fear.

column2: bozo, 65-74 (Patient)
column9: I walked around with my jaw clenched for years, and slept poorly. I was fine after xanax, but the doctor said it could cause balance problems in older people. Nothing else seems to work as well.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Xanax 2 years ago to help me cope with a stressful job.  I started with .5 mg.  Soon I built up a tolerance, and my doctor prescribed me 1mg 4 times a day.  When I built up a tolerance to that I started taking more....at one time.  I have become dependent on this drug.  Part of me wants to quit taking it, but the addicted part tells me I NEED it.  I let this drug ruin my life.  I lost my job, my boyfriend of 10 years, and my parents' and friends' trust.  I wish I had never heard of Xanax.

column2: LMR3, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Since childhood, I've had bouts of "nervousness." After getting married and having 3 children fairly close (the nervousness subsided during prenancy) I started having what I called MAJOR "panic attacks" I made many trips to the emergency room, thinking I was losing my mind. My symptoms were hard to explain and hard to understand ( to anyone but me ) I was terribly nauseous, anxious... I could not relax ( which everyone told me to do ) An attack would hit me at any time. During the day, the middle of the night, and all I could do was pace. Although I never had thoughts of suicide, I was starting to feel like I was lsoing my mind. I admitted myself into a hospital..."mental ward" and was diagnosed with stress/anxiety, and panic issues/depression. I was assigned therapy. and was given Xanax, and Wellbutrin. This was 10 yrs. ago. Occasionally, I still have the panic attacks, and they are rough. If it was not for the Xanax, which I take AS prescribed, I could not enjoy my family, or my life. When I take it, I do not feel any kind of HIGH. It makes me able to take a breath, relax, and go on with normal life. I am aware of all the Xanax hype,and yes it IS extremely addictive. I just stay fully aware of my meds and take them as I should.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
Logan, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Xanax has been the most effective and most troublesome of anti-panic meds I have tried - troublesome in regards to the short duration variants and dealing with the "rebound effect". Xanax has evolved into many forms, I found the XR version fairly safe and effective, tho expensive, the short or "fast acting" formulations I find a"rebound" effect if I exceed 2mg, but any formulation has been very effective at near-instant PA relief.  As for the social stigma aspect - even within the medical community, I do not understand that, these are not meds to be taken lightly, and the condition is very disabling -  people have undoubtedly scammed doctors to get meds, but a blanket position on certain meds is prejudicial and does "harm" the undeserving.

column2: lvanderwall@hotmail.com, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 45yr female, wife, mother. Between money issues, job anxiety and life demands I had a panic attack. Didnt sleep for days couldnt stop my racing mind. Prescribed .25 every 4/6 hours as needed. Took as presc. for the first week and then tried to lower. It has taken time, but I only take as needed now. I am very healthy and sensitive to meds, I didnt have any problems with this, just quieted my mind so I could function. Dont be scared of it, and dont be so hard on yourself if you need help. We all need it sometimes. I had no side effects and feel so much better knowing I have it if I need it. column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking xanax off and on for several years. When I was younger, I had full blown panic attacks, had no idea how to handle it or what to do. I just lived in fear all the time. If I wasn't having a panic attack, I was afraid I was going to have one. Just a really bad cycle. A few years ago, I was prescribed xanax, which works so great for me. I was in such bad shape that I was "anxious" about taking the "anxiety" medication! But it turned out fine, it helped so much. The other medications for anxiety and panic, such as anti-depressants, I had a bad reaction to, I hated them, I won't take them. But xanax has no side effects, except occassionally it will make me feel a little sleepy for a brief time. And I have the option of only taking medication when I need to, instead of every day. Having this medication has greatly improved my life, and my condition. I haven't had a panic attack in years, and I am able to reduce and control my anxiety. I have never had to take this med more than once in a day. One of the great things is that it takes away the symptoms, but leaves you perfectly able to function, work, drive, do whatever you need to do. My dosage is .5 and I usually only take half a pill. Just that much works fine. I do sometimes worry about addiction, but as long as you keep aware of that possibility, and your doctor carefully monitors your usage, it should not be a problem at all. Coming from someone who has lived with panic and anxiety for 25 years, I can honestly say this has helped more than anything else.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
noxan4me, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed xanax for extreme anxiety.  At first it worked along with an antidepressant i was taking. Then i became used to the xanax dose i thing was .5mg.  When i could no longer deal with the addictive effects, i decided to go cold turkey.  i ended up in the emergency room shaking.  before that, i actually went in my bathroom and jumped for an hour.  i could not get myself together or stop shaking my leg.  It took a week for me to "detox".  i couldn't sleep; it was like i was losing my mind.  I was out of work for two weeks. I'm on klonopin now 3 times daily.  I've had much better results.  I would not suggest anyone take xanax unless you are ready for the addictiveness and the detox.  I was told that i was supposed to gradually decrease my dosage to come down but i wanted that stuff out of my body. Be careful; this stuff works to a certain extent, but is super addictive.

column2: nae0071, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: PLEASE LISTEN TO MY STORY! I am a 24 yr old that has been on & off xanax for a few years. I was first prescribed xanax for panic attacks. Meanwhile both Zoloft & Cymbalta wasn't working for depresson, therefore, they decided to dose me up on xanax just to mentally get through how miserable i was with depression. I couldn't think straight, couldn't remember anything, felt no happiness for anything, and worst of all i was wanting anything to make me feel normal or get my mind off the awful depression. The dr kept on telling me to take xanax to quit having weird sucidial thoughts. Although my head was telling me one thing, my heart was saying this isn't right.I was in living hell! The xanax helped ease everything and at times made me feel great, kind of a high.I have never abused drugs nor will i ever! I was prescribed this medicine to help my anxiety and depression and they kept me on it for 5 years. What people do not know is how dangerous of a drug it is. I had to visit about 15 different dr's this past year because of weird symptoms due to the drug; double vision with everything seeming slanted, dizziness, vertigo, depression, and on and on. I am here to tell you xanax is only a two week drug to help with anxiety. Please, Please do research before you take this drug. There are other anxiety meds to take that are non addictive and ask about them first. Also, start taking gabba because it effects your brain the same as xanax but its non addictive and non drowsy. I just got back from an orthomolecular dr to get me off all of the drugs. Went from taking 3 1/2 mgs a day to .75 mg. It has been hell even taking supplements to ease the withdrawls. It will effect so many different aspects of your life because it is a depressant such as alchoal is. My memory is slowly returning. At one point I couldn't remember how 2 even spell easy words. I beg users to do research because the drs are not waring you about the fatal drug. Plz e-mail me w/ANY questions. Janaed2000@hotmail.com

column9: I was prescribed the peach .5 dose 3x a day in 2000 to help with my anxiety, sleeplessness, and inability to deal w/the stress in my life. Around 2002 the dosage was increased to the blue 1.0 3x a day then last year when my dad past away it was increased to the white 2.0 3x a day. I've tried every sleep aide but nothing works or they make me feel drugged out or not w/it the next morning. This is the only med I have found that helps me sleep, helps w/my anxiety, works w/in 15 to 20 minutes & doesn't have those affects. I take it to sleep at night now & only on the days when I get really stressed or my anxiety kicks in because of the fact that it does make me sleepy & I don't function well during the day on it. It does help & is a wonderful med but I don't like the fact that it's so addictive.If I knew then what I know now I wouldn't have ever let my dr prescribe it to me. He did try all other options before prescribing it to me. I would recommend trying all other option before having your dr. prescribe it because of the fact it is highly addictive & the w/drawals are not something you want to experience. I would give anything to have a med that is as effective for sleeplessness, stress, feeling anxious, panic attacks & anxiety as xanax but isn't addictive like xanax. I don't recommend going off this med w/out your dr. supervision or just stopping it all at once. column2: Bighonkinwalrus, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug works very well for me. It is however impossible to suppress anxiety with Xanax alone. You MUST be willing to redirect your anxious behaviors and thoughts. Xanax works extraordinarily well for me. But if you let your thoughts take over, you can easily override its effects.My main time I use Xanax is to combat the nervousness of a long morning commute to school. I take one (1), (.5mg) pill in the morning and I am okay for the day. I can like I said, override its effects if I am bent on concentrating on my nervousness. I have taken this medicine (NOT regularly; as needed), for nearly 3 years now. There are no lasting side effects for me. I don't drink alcohol so I don't know the medicine would interact (Its not recommended). I do not feel dizzy which is the most common side effect and if I am really uptight before bedtime, Xanax allows me to mellow out and have a good night's sleep. Overall I am very satisfied with the results of this medicine.

column2: 55-64 Male  (Patient)
Relieved, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: These reviews helped as much as the medication!  I'm so happy to not feel alone anymore. Panic attacks are frightening and the 'fixation' on one aspect, such as breathing, heartbeat, etc. really adds to the problem.  I also find I get scared that I will always be 'that way' (stuck in an attack that will never end)...possibly losing my mind.  It is horrible.  I started by taking 1/2 of a .25mg and in less than ten minutes...relief!  I use it as needed, but for some reason am reluctant, if not outright afraid, to ask my doctor for/about daily treatment to keep a more calm level daily instead of reacting when something happens.  I guess its the stigma, feeling less like the 'strong' adult male I should be and feeling more 'weak' and not able to handle life like a normal person.  I also worry, what if it doesn't work?  Sometimes during the attack I am afraid to take it because what would I do if it didn't work?  That's where the 'stuck there forever' anxiety comes from I believe. One good thing about this medication is how fast it works.  I know what I am going to write next might be part of a psychological placebo effect, but, as soon as I take that little half pill, the panic attack lessens.  I mean instantly.  And the thought of having them in the cabinet alone sometimes helps.  I tell myself 'well, I'll just take a pill' and sometimes I feel good enough just with that thought that I don't need it right at that time, if at all.  I keep two in my wallet and two in the car - and I laugh at myself over that, but, it helps.  If you are reading this, I hope it helped.  Stay healthy, keep positive and use your faith in whatever form it may take. Oh, and take the pill already!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I keep one with me at all times. We call it the "Public Safety" pill. I try not to take it if I don't have to. I am prescribed to take it for sleep, but to save them I take Melatonin at night for sleep. I have learned not to tell anyone that I have them, because I had an ex steal them from me. My Dr. didn't believe me at first so be very careful with your prescriptions. I have known people that have died from overdose on Xanax, so don't believe the reviews that say they are safe to take in large quantities. It is to be used for relief not for a high!!!

column9: I have used Xanax for a long time, and it has always worked for me.  I suffer from Chronic Pain, and sleep is something that is frequently difficult to obtain, since the discomfort levels keep me from relaxing enough to get the rest I need.  Over the years, I've gone from 1/4mg to 1mg per use; so yes, over time the amount needed increases.  Still, it lets me sleep without the muzziness that pure sleep-aids cause in the morning.  It also is useful when I get tense, since that can cause muscles to cramp in my back (damaged spine and cord), so it's helpful in that manner although it is not a muscle relaxant per se.  I've found it's wisest to take the smallest dose that will do the job, since over time it will need to be increased; and the smallest increase is always the best.

column2: 87_blueangel, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I started having panic attacks at age 20 (although I didn't know that is what they were. All I knew that even when I was completely happy and relaxed, reading a good book or listening to music, my heart would start racing and I would be gulping for oxygen. As time passed, the attacks became more frequent and more severe. Many times I called for an ambulance because I was sure I was having a heart attack. I continually went to family doctors and they provided no advice. Never thought of going to a psychiatrist. Since the general M.D.'s offered no help, ended up self medicating with alcohol. Which only made matters worse. I got very lucky and ran across an ad looking for volunteers suffering from anxiety to try a new medication. After months of testing, the new medication did nothing for me. The psychiatrist running the test, gave me a book to read about anxiety w/ panic attacks, and put me on Xanax. Wow! I have taken it for about 25 years. Quit drinking because I no longer needed to try to heal myself. I was amazed to find out that people become addicted to it. To me it was no more than taking a vitamin pill. Didn't make me feel drozy or anything, just stopped the constant flow of adrenelin. Saved my life.

column2: American, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have a very stressful job. I am a firefighter and see very disturbing things at work. Not to mention i am put in very stressful sitations almost every shift.At work one day started having chest pains and difficulty breathing. Working at the fire station i told the guys to take me to the hospital. Scared the crap out of them because i told them i felt like i was gonna die, anyway, after every test known to man was done at the hospital, nothing was found and i was sent home. The next few days were fine and i thought it was a one time thing. Then one day out of the blue another panic attack hit me and fortunately my mom was over visiting and she had a Xanax with her for her anxiety attacks, i took one and within 15 mins i was feeling normal. I went to the doctor and said i want some xanax pills and she gave me a perscription and i have been using them since. This was about four years ago. I am 37 now. I could not imagine myself without them and i am one to avoid taking any medications. They have saved me numerous times, at work, home, out with the family, too many times to count. I stick with the .25 mg as needed. If you have panic attacks, have anxiety proplems, even just feeling anxious on a daily basis like i do this drug will change your life. Use it, dont abuse it and it will make you feel normal again and you can enjoy life. I hope this helps someone like it helped me. Anxiety almost ruined my life.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I went through a series of extremely stressful and out of the ordinary situations about four and a half years ago.  I had already recovered quite nicely from PPD in the years before and hoped to never see another psychiatric drug in my life.  Too bad that wasn't in the cards for me.  My husband was diagnosed with a rare and typically fatal cancer and Hurricane Katrina hit our home town during the same month.  I couldn't handle the stresses of natural disaster and brain surgery.  I wasn't eating or sleeping properly and I have a daughter to care for.  My panic attacks became overwhelming and after a particularly emotional visit to the NICU, a nurse brought me to the ER and had me do a consult with the psychiatrist on call.  She prescribed .5mg of xanax twice a day.  I think I only used that much when my husband was under the knife but I don't know how else I could've handled the insane situation my family was thrown into.  Please don't be afraid of this medication because it has the potential to be abused.  Responsible drs are there for their patients and make sure everything is going smoothly.  I still need it for my panic attacks, which now are rare, due to therapy and a great support system, but I know there are difficult times around the corner and I will not try to cope with them alone.  The stress on me and my daughter is simply not worth my apprehension about doctor's appts.  Good luck to all.

column9: yes this drug works to well. i also suffer severe chronic pain, recently i moved and had to find a new DR. in the mean time my meds. run out. also take 100mg ms contin twice daily.well needless to say you can have seizures stopping suddenly. I scared my son to death one nite i had went into seizures and rolled out of the bed or he may not have known and i may not be here today. so if you take this drug for a long period of time don't take more than prescribed and run out.I was in the hospital for 4 day's and they said it was from xanax withdrawl.Be carefull with this drug and do not take more than you are prescribed and run out, and not tell your DR because you are scared they will take them away from you,i had 7 seizures beleive me it can happen to you.

column2: celestia, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: i have found out by taking xanax,it had helped me deal with everyday experiences without feeling anxiety to a point of calmness to where i could work with all problems involving with my job,my family, and give sound advise to others. my mind is clear and focused. i have had no side effects at all. i can feel when i am starting to feel uncomfortable so i know i should take my med before i have an attack of anxiety.i don't always have to take as many as prescribed because i know when it is a stressful day or not. although they say it is a possible habit forming, i believe that is up to you.i should take up to 4 a day if needed which i do at times but other times i can get by with 1.it has helped me get through some rough times,otherwise i wouldn't have been able to support my children and run my household. something as simple as going to the grocery store for food,and going through the check out isle was a chore.i'd have an axiety attack and leave everything on the counter and have to get out of the building.so embarrasing! i highly suggest this drug for anyone that has anxiety attacks as long as you respect it and use it as prescribed!i am able to do anything as far as being in public again including getting back into my music and being on stage again with confidence!the only other med i take is ibuprofen for my joints.i'm now 54 yrs old and doing great! i have taken xanax since 1992 and have you ever seen a recall on this med? compared to all the newer meds that has came out to help us?

column2: bonuswoman, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: kmpqvz, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed Xanax over a year ago for panic attacks on airplanes.  Also, was prescribed Propranolol.  So now I take .5 Xanax and Propoanolol 30 min before the plane takes off.  I'm fine.  Sometimes I need another 0.25 Xanax during turbulence or on decent.  I had a very scary flight experience 8-9 years ago and never got past it.  I have occasionally used the Xanax to reduce my anxiety at other times too.  Be careful since an overdose can be a significant issue.  Xanax doesn't work for me as a long term solution for generalized anxiety disorder since its half life is so short - I'm using Lexapro for that - 20 mg daily.  It seems to work.  I also have Ambien at night - when needed.  All this was not prescribed by my doctor, I saw a psychiatrist.  The only concern I have is the Ambien - when I don't take it I can wake up several times during the night - no big deal though.  When I do take it, I don't wake up until morning.  I'd like to reduce my usage, but I'm being careful to ensure that I get adequate sleep.  That really seems to help my mood.  Along with regular exercise - dopamine.

column9: This is the greatest medicine on earth.I take this at a low dosage along with an anti depressant (Nardil) and works for me.The whole trick to this med is the proper dosage.It is absolutely habit forming and never go cold turkey or you will get sick. Learn what your body needs and some days you will need more. The docs are stingy with this drug so you have to store some like a squirrel. If I have a rough day I might have to take extra maybe 50% more on a given day. Most docs realize this is habit forming and slow to give it out. Most days I can get by with a total of 1 mg but some days needs more. Some people take 4 times this much so the dosage varies a lot.

column2: zephyress, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I read the first 75 reviews here, and most of them are similar to my story.  Some of you may have a similar story to mine. Here is my story...I have been on .25 ml xanax for about 8 years, usually only taking half at a time. BUT only averaging about 1 pill ONCE a week because I was only dealing w/ stress from my job, n stress from divorce with a newborn (13 yrs ago), n had most difficulty during the "depressing" winters.  I've been living with my senior parents since, and have had my casino waitress job for 18 yrs.NOW, suddenly my life completely changed.  I now have a young teen boy, who is a great kid. I recently lost my 18-yr job, still living w parents.  My job was my only stability.  I also recently lost my 13-yr-old dog, who went thru all my stress and problems w/ me... I'm definitely feeling grief and family loss. I recently graduated from Med Assisting school (since I lost my job) and cannot find a job, its been 6 months.  I stressed over getting all A's, which I did. And I stressed over getting an A on the National test.  My father also had a massive heart attack same time as my test - he miraculously survived, and living with him makes me worry about him more than usual.  There's a few more drastic changes in my life this past year.  Which brings me to my point - for the past 6 months i have experienced the extreme anxiety disorder symptoms: heavy n crampy chest, sharp pains in my left chest, tingles, fear, cannot breath, more fear, lots of tremors, extreme chills, heart palpitations and pounding heart that is constant all day.  These symptoms started out to average 2-3 /week. NOW suddenly this week its been constant all day every day, and I live in FEAR. This altered my life completely in one week. I even fear taking xanax more than Im used to. I also feel "seizur-ic" AT times.  In ER few times 6 mo ago and heart/lungs checked.  I now fear that THIS IS MY LIFE... FEAR n Anxiety constantly all day everyday n takin xanax more. WIll I EVER GET BETTER

This caused a severe manic episode, I was out driving in the middle of the night, got pulled over by police on suspicion of DUI.  The first time I withdrew without weaning off gradually I could not stop vomiting.  Also, if you have this drug in your home, be careful who you tell; there is a substantial street value and had my prescriptions stolen at least 3 times by so-called friends of my teenagers.  I finally weaned myself off once and for all about 5 years ago; however, I miss the ability to sleep since I now suffer from fibromyalgia and could use Xanax for sleep, but I don't want to go thru the addiction and withdrawel again.
My Dr, prescribed a small dose 2 1/2 mgfor occasional sleepnessless. It works, I donot take it regularely, only when needed

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Xanax is very good very someone with a nervous disorder.  The only problem I see with this drug is if you run out.  I am on 2MG stick Xanax.  I ran out a couple of times when my doctor was out of town and I had a seizure.  The last time I had three seizures before the EMT staff could get me transported to the ER.  So if you are on large doses of this medication, like I am on 5 a day, do not come off of this medication suddenly.  They do not put this warning on the bottle, but it is a possible danger if you do not come off of the medication slowly.  I hope this helps others taking this medication.

column2: Starburst, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have taken this medicine for apprx 10 + years. It not only helps with my panic attacks, my over anxiety, my sleep, irritibility is less, depression is less, also I have had less occurance of ulcers and other issues related to IBD. It helps me in soo many ways. I have also found that when my tolerance is getting to high we switch to Valium to give my body time to reduce its tolerance while still being able to continue with a medicine that also helps. When my tolerance to that grows we switch back. I love this medicine also because it is not something that has to build in your system for weeks to work. Yes, it should be taken for preventitive measures, but it does not have to be taken if it is not needed. Of course each situation is differnt. This is one of my meds that help me the most in many areas. It has saved me from many undesirable situations. But KNOW it doesn't do it a lone. I take an active role in implamenting many other learned techniques too. It only makes it to where they are within my control (with some work)and that is all I need to give what I am learning to do myself a chance to be practiced! Thanks for creating an aid to help me gain control over a lot of my issues!

column2: mel927, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I am a 25 year old female full-time student and I have had severe panic attacks since the age of 19. I was first prescribed .25mg of xanax 2 years ago and have since upped the dosage to .5mg. The smaller dosage didn't really help that much, but when i moved to .5mg I really noticed a difference. The main point I want to make is that while xanax does help if you feel a panic attack coming on, or if you are in a situation you are nervous about, but it DOES NOT prevent panic attacks from occuring. It is a tranquilizer. I am going back to my doctor to see about getting on an antidepressant that is used for panic. I will, however, continue taking xanax as needed. I am a little concerned about addiction to xanax, but I feel that a doctor can help ween you off. Hope this helps.

column2: PaulCarbo99, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I struggle from why my shrink called a mixture of anxiety issues ranging from general to social anxiety disorder.  This medicine has been a life/job saver for me.  Instead of getting so irritable. I'm able to take a step back and put the whole situation into perspective and realize that most of of the times things I stress over are not that serious.  I'm currently prescribed 3mg xr 2X daily, and 1mg regular to use as needed. Even though I take it as prescribed, memory loss is a big side effect for me.  I take a camera everywhere I go and it helps me jog my memory.  There was an epsidode where I actually had surgery on my knee and somehow lost/or someone stole my medicine.  I had an appointment two weeks later for my shrink.  I thought I would be okay not taking the medication.   Bad call.  I made it two days before having severe panic attacks. After trying to fight this for another five days I couldn't take it anymore.  I went to see my primary care physician who gave me enough to last me until my doctors appt. After then I did some research I came to find out if you're not winded of the medication over time you could have a seizure or even die.  So overall when I take my meds as needed, I'm a well balanced easy to get along with individual, the way I should be.  My point is do NOT try and just stop taking your meds.  Consult your doctor if you do wish to get off them so you both can set up a plan to wean you off.  Before I finish some side effects I felt were withdrawal feeling which mainly were I was extremely irritable, I felt creepy crawly over my skin.  Whenever I spoke on the phone It was like I could hear amplified which frustrated me more.  Also whenever someone as much as rubbed me the creepy crawly feeling was intensified and I was quick to yell and tell the person (ex) to get away from me even though I cared about them and wanted them.  I hope this helps someone and you don't make the same mistakes that I did.  I wouldn't wish that on anyone!

Have been on low dose of 1 mg for a year and now up to 1.5 and am completely addicted.  I don't know where the line between my legitimate anxiety and my withdrawal symptoms lies.  I hate this drug. Only take as needed, not every day, or you, to will feel like you are fighting a losing battle.  I am depressed and wake in the mornign with a horrible sense of dread.  I often cry every morning.  I do not think I am on a therapeutic dose of this drug at all.

column9: I suffer from PTSD and anxiety disorder. My attacks are so severe that I cannot breathe, I get numb from head to toe, I vomit and my muscles give out on me.I have been on Xanax for several years now and am prescribed .5 Mg 3 times a day. I only take 1/2 once a day, sometimes twice ONLY as needed, so somedays I dont take it at all. I cannot say enough about how much Xanax has helped me. Addictive or not, all I can say is that my dose has never been increased and I only take it as needed. I have suffered no short term memory loss. I am a single mother of 2 teenage daughters and they are extremely understanding of my condition. I do have to see my Dr every 3 months to get a new prescription, but it is well worth living life to its fullest (and much cheaper than a trip to the ER). I feel alive and under control and able to enjoy the simplest things without jumping out of my skin everytime I see a black truck or someone covers my eyes or taps me on the shoulder. Thanks to my Dr. for giving me my life back, my kids thank him too.

I asked my Dr. about Xanax and he first prescribed the .5mg to take as needed. This was good but had to remember to take all the time. Now I take 2mg xr and it is wonderful. I just feel normal!

column9: I am Bipolar I, sometimes have severe insomnia (last episode lasted 3 weeks), am manic most of the time. Xanax helps me calm down and sleep. I only take it when needed, so sometimes I find myself taking one from an expired bottle. I can go for months without it, but when I start feeling nervous, anxious and confused, I need it. The best part is that it puts me to sleep within a half hour. What a blessing! When I feel crappy and anxious, sleep is the best thing for me. The long term side-effect is that my memory is shot. This does me no good when it comes time to take midterms & finals at school. Luckily, the school accommodates for "mental illness" students and they provide tutors and extra time for testing. I have never gotten addicted, because I do not use it as directed. Use as needed and you will get good results from it.

column2: nancy neptune, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had panic disorder for 18 years. Before there was Xanax, I was put on some very dreadful MAO inhibitors that made me unwell and did nothing. Less than a year later Xanax came out and it was a miracle. No more extreme fear and no more anorexia. I had attacks all day long so bad that I couldn't eat. I thought I had Pheochromocytosis, a bad disease of the adrenal glands. I was given a bunch of tests to make sure I didn't.I would not be alive today without Xanax, it has stopped the attacks and I've been on the same dosage for 15 years. .50 2x's a day.For all you people who keep harping on the fear of addiction, just stop it. You need it or you wouldn't be on it. Would you be worried that if you had to take blood pressure meds the rest of your life you'd be addicted? In a sense you are, you'd be taking a risk to stop them, and you need  them.So stop pulling your hair out about being a drug addict, you're not.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: While highly addictive I still think it's good results outweigh it's bad on me. In a sense, it is a magic pill for me as I know that if I take one as soon as the panic starts to rise I will only have to wait 25 to 35 minutes for the medication to start working. This has allowed me to leave my home, to drive, to go hiking, etc... In other words it has given me my life back. I do not take it 3 times a day. I only take it when I am confronted with a panic attack or severe anxiety. This way prevents me from getting addicted which would be very easy, believe me. You do get that alcohol-like buzz from xanax, at least I do anyway. If your doctor won't prescibe this for you then you need a new doctor. I suffered for years for nothing other than the notion my doctor had in believing I would become addicted. What's worse though? Going through the hell of panic attacks or being addicted to a drug that stops them? Again, I don't take them unless I need them but when I do it works. This has been my experience - yours may vary.

column9: I was just diagnosed with uterine cancer on May 18th.  I have to wait 2 1/2 weeks to see the specialist. I can relax, I'm sleeping and eating again and not consumed with negative thoughts and worry all day long.  I am able to function at work while taking it.  I am grateful that this drug is helping me get through this very difficult time in my life.

column2: mistyocean, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I was hit suddenly with a sense of not being connected to my body when I was 19. After going to several psychiatrists and telling my parents, they diagnosed me with "depersonalization". Xanax didn't exist at that time, so I was put on Valium. It made the sensations stop. When Xanax came on the market I was switched to it. I'm now 53 and still cannot function without the Xanax. I take three 1 mg tablets a day along with an antidepressant. My tolerance is high after being on this drug such a long time, but it has allowed me to have a life instead of being in the er or curled up in my room. Doctors try to take me off of it because it's addicting, which by now I find a joke. After all these years and if it works, don't change things. The only down side is that you MUST take it as prescribed and not take too much because if you have been on it a long time, give out too soon, after two days, you will be jerking, hallucinating, and can have seizures. I have done this in the past and I truly thought I would die. So if you don't need it, don't take it. If you do, be prepared for hell if the doctor tries to take you off of it.

column2: DocXYZM, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am dealing with Methadone withdrawal actually, which is my diagnosed use for either Xanax or Valium.  I am downing my dosage to get off the Methadone.  Xanax 1mg tid helps me with the muscle restlessness, the inability to sleep, the anhedonia from lack of dopamine production, the dysphoria, from same lack of natural opiate production, and it generally calms the anxiety that goes with the horrible effects of coming off of precription narcotic analgesics.  I would not advise people to use benzos long term, or the withdrawal is very dangerous.  The only 2 meds that most insurance will pay for inpatient detox from are alcohol and benzodiazepines.  The seizures with both are very serious, potentially fatal with the right set of circumstances.  Used correctly, however, Xanax (or Val.) makes the withdrawal from Morphine/Methadone/Codiene/Oxy or hydrocodone tolerable - but incomplete alone.  They treat the symptoms, but not the condition.  Also, Xanax is helpful for panic attacks, but not so much after an attack is in mid-episode.  Good preventative agent for panic attacks and generalized anxiety disorder.  If you TRULY are suffering with anxiety or panic dis., and you REALLY want to get better, you need to mix the Xanax with counseling.  Look for a counselor who does Cognitive Behavioral Therapy,aka C.B.T.  They use techniques like Systematic Desensitization, if you can identify some situations that cause your attacks, but most ppl can't.  So they teach them Relaxation Techniques, to sort of put your self into a self-hynotic state of calmness.  It is basically a good diversion while the episode passes on its on.  Well, I hope this helps someone out.  I studied pharmacology as a req. for my undergraduate degree, and I am in grad school now working on a degree in MPH (Master Public Health), in an area called Epidemiology. So I am not completely "full of it!"  I also have some obvious personal experience with addiction, stemming from military service in the sandbox. DocXYZM

column2: Jeannie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: sparky04, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My doc. and I think xanax might work for me but I'm not too keen on the idea of taking an addictive med. The therapy really ISN'T working for me though. I just took xanax a couple hours ago for my first time. I've been researching a lot of different meds and options. I'm kinda testing the waters with this one but from what I've read it seems to be down to this or Klonopin (not yet tried). My anxiety/ panic is triggered by something in particular and does not come out of the blue like for most people. So I took 3 .25mg and let them dissolve under my tongue. Waited 15-20 mins and did something I know would trigger high anxiety or a panic attack. I felt a little anxiousness but nothing serious. I know these meds work different for everyone. I'll definitely be giving xanax a chance. The only downside that I'm seeing is the addictiveness that can develop. I'll definitely be taking it on a as needed basis! I do feel a little "zoned out" right now kinda like a small alcohol buzz feeling, kinda tired, and some clumsiness. Other than that I can still disguise it and act "sober" from what I can see. Hopefully this helped someone like all your posts helped me. Good luck!!!P.S. If anyone out there has any good info that could be helpful, please let me know.

column2: Jeff, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started having trouble sleeping a couple of months ago. I went to the doc and she thought it was associated with anxiety and prescribed xanax. I was worried about relying on a medication to sleep or for anything in general. So I only took it a couple of times and it worked but I stopped hoping I could sleep without it. For the next couple of months my sleeping problems worsened to teh point where I couldn't sleep for more than 2 hours and my lack of sleep started really affecting my life in many bad ways. I didn't have energy, bad moods, worry, and started being seriously affected by anxiety. So ultimatley I decided to take the doctors initial advice and take the xanax for a little while to relearn how to sleep. It has worked fantastic!! I've taken it for 5 days consecutively and I feel normal again. I take 1mg an hour before I want to go to sleep and I sleep very well. Sometimes I still wake up but I fall back asleep easily. I have young children so it's almost impossible to sleep all the way through the night without interuption but xanax helps me sleep deeply and fall back asleep when I wake up. Also, I haven't felt any of the groggy side effects the next day like I do with Tylenol PM or similar. As long as I can stop taking it without problems it is a miracle drug. I plan to continue to take it for another week or so and then stop. I'll repost afterwards and let everyone know how it goes. Good luck with your sleeping!! I've found out the hard way that the effects of not sleeping way out way taking the xanax. I'd suggest trying it temporarily along with making life changes to improve your sleeping habits.

column2: tauru901, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
cathy, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I began taking 2mg daily about 20 years ago for general panic. Helped right away. No more fear of open spaces, could walk without getting dizzy and my head felt straight. Downside to this pill, is that it is so addictive! I am now on 4mg daily, and in the past couple of years am noticing I am animated, loud, full of life, talking very rapidly and way too much. It became obvious to me and then I overheard different people mention they thought I was "on something". It also caused me to become very complacent with my job---I stayed in a low paying job, simply because it was easy--and on the xanax---sort of fun. I also was in a ridiculous relationship with a man that I never would have been with if not for the xanax. I found that I loved everyone, the world was rosy, and I didn't really give a fig about anything. Now I cannot get off this stuff. After all these years of being medicated, I have no idea what my real personality is, and often wonder how different my life would have turned out without xanax. Made some terrible choices while on this, not realizing I was "high". Am now seeing an md to try to get off this. Do not start this stuff or you can't get through a day without it! Should be banned.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: This drug has changed my life! I used to suffer panic attacks, particularly for public speaking. If I take .5 to .75 I can function normally and not stress speaking, important meetings, awkward social engagements, etc.If I am stressed over something or cannot turn my mind off to sleep, .25 helps with that.I take it only when I need it and have never felt it addictive. The only issues I ever have are doctors who question why you take it and how long you have taken it.My wife took the drug to help her with panic attacks that she got after her first husband had died. When we dated over ten years ago, she saw that I had a anxiety and panic disorder, particularly associated with public speaking.The generic is alprazolam. It costs $3-$4 to get a 30 pill prescription.Best money I ever spent and what a God send it has been for my life.I have never seen a more effective medication to addressing immediate stress and panic disorders.

column2: Jessica, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have dealt with panic attacks and anxiety for years.I was on Buspar for 6 months and I didn't like the way they made me feel at all. So  I started taking Xanax about 2yrs. ago. I have had no side affects and I do not feel they are habit forming for me. Everyone's different though. I'm the type of person who hates taking meds. So to depend on this drugs must mean they diffidently work.

column2: Diane, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've suffered from Panic/Anxiety Disorder for over 30 yrs. When Xanax first came out it was wonderful. Now doctors don't like it..too addicting. I never found it addicting or given a 'high' feeling..I felt normal. As docs want you to get off of xanax they put you on all kinds of other psych meds. They are free to give those out. Zoloft was added to my meds about 6 years ago. It helped some but never stops the panic/amxiety disorder to make you feel 'human' like Xanax does. I tried to reduce the Zoloft to the point of getting off of it. Big mistake. The side effects for getting off Zoloft are horrible. Numbness in the mouth and hands, crying all the time, jitters, feeling like your skin is coming off. The side effects are far worse than continuing to take the Zoloft 100mg a night. Soon I will give it another try to get off Zoloft. Xanax works the best for me without addiction or a drugged feeling. Good luck finding a doc who will prescribe it without making you see a psychiatrist! I recently moved and after some research on the doctor and an initial visit..I am lucky to find one that still believes it works and works well for many of us. We shouldn't be taking meds on a whim, as ordered by a doctor, when we don't need or want them.

column9: I WENT UNDIAGNOSED INTO MY TEENS W/ANXIETY & DEPRESSION WHICH RESULTED IN ANOTHER CONDITION CALLED SI(self injury) SO, I STATRTED CUTTING MYSELF(age 16) I DECIDED TO GET HELP, BUT BY THAT TIME, 5 yrs. & OVER 150+ SCARS WERE ON MY LOWER INNER-ARMS,FORE ARMS,UPPER ARMS,TOP OF MY LEG,STOMACH & WRISTS(suicide attempts).I CUT MYSELF BECAUSE I COULDN'T HANDLE REALITY(eg.:public speaking,fighting w/mate,boss or co-workers,etc.)& CUTTING ALWAYS HELPED ME TO EXPRESS THE PAIN I WAS FEELING ON THE INSIDE, TO THE OUTSIDE.IT DIDN'T HURT BECAUSE IT'S MIND OVER MATTER.UNFORTUNATELY IT LANDED ME IN THE ER TO GET SOWN UP, WAY TO MANY TIMES!SO I GOT HELP @ THE AGE OF 21 & THE DOCTOR PUT ME ON XANAX, I GUESS YOU COULD SAY THAT IT SAVED MY LIFE, BECAUSE I WAS ABLE TO TAKE IT BEFORE GOING TO WORK IF I NEW IT WAS GOING TO BE A DAY FROM *ELL OR TAKE IT @ WORK(general manager in the car-business 10 yrs.)IF THE DAY TURNED BAD WHICH WAS OFTEN,ESPECIALLY FOR ME BECAUSE I WAS A WOMAN WORKING HER WAY FROM SALES TO MGMT IN A "MANS" WORLD. BUT BE VERY,VERY, VERY, CAREFUL!!IT IS EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE!!!I BECAME ADDICTED TO IT AND WAS TAKING IN EXCESS OF 200+,1mg PILLS A MONTH. THAT LASTED FOR ABOUT 4yrs. I WAS GETTING MY RX OF 120 & BUYING THE OTHER 80-100 PILLS OFF THE "STREET".THEN I REALIZED @ THE AGE OF 29 THAT LIFE IS TOO SHORT & I WANT TO ENJOY MY TIME W/MY SON,FAMILY & FIANCE. WHO WANTS TO GO THROUGH LIFE IN A DAZE? NOT ME! I'M STILL ON THE XANAX & I'M FORTUNATE THAT I HAD THE SENSE TO GET A HANDLE ON IT, NOW I TAKE ONLY 2-3 A DAY & I LOVE MYSELF MORE FOR THAT, & I LOVE MY LIFE! I HOPE THIS INFO HELPS SOME OF YOU OUT THERE. GOOD LUCK! :o)

column2: StephanieCC, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Xanax has treated my condition going on 3-1/2 yrs. I have been trying to get off the medication because of its side effects for a yr. now. I am prescribed 2mg 3x a day but am only taking 1 pill unless I cant sleep then I take 1 more. I am finding it very difficult to get off of...almost like a junkie. I AM TRULY SCARRED. My doctor keeps me on it and has me do a check up once every 3 months. I had to quit going to the doctor because I lost my insurance so now I need to find a way to kick the habit...so to speak. I am truly scarred that I am going to have a seizure if I just stop completely. I have expressed this concern but the conversation seems to take a different turn off of the subject. I really wish they could develop a drug that was not addictive but treated for the same condition.

column2: Matt, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Of course, this medication works. Make sure to have a plan with your doctor before starting Xanax or any other benzodiazepine. These medications cause dependence VERY quickly for most people.  If you use this in high doses or for prolonged periods (2-4 weeks or more), consider your risks for withdrawal when stopping this drug.  Never abruptly stop taking Xanax or other benzos without tapering down, especially if you are experiencing withdrawal.  The withdrawal can lead to dangerous episodes of anxiety or convulsions. So.... use it short term, and seek other forms of therapy for your anxiety like counseling.

column2: Spaz no more, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Had essential tremor since elemantary school years.  Was nicknamed "Spaz" by Jr. highschool years.  Now I'm Rx'd 4 mg. per day. I take 0.5 mg. upon waking to prevent 1st anxiety. Then 1 mg. in early evening to calm me from day's events & that is usually all I need.  But if something really bad scares me, I have the option of upto 2 more doses. / At 1st it made me drowsy & I didn't like that, but things normalized w/in 2 weeks.  Especially when I started breaking morning tab in half.  I like that I can now leave to house to do business without the embarassment of looking nervous.  People are suspicious of shaky people when asking questions like at bank when have a large check to cash that perfectly legal. Spouse liked that I was not so self conscious for intimacy.  I have calmed down to have a normalized sex life after waiting 20 years. I like the built in "can't get addicted" b/c if take too much, it won't work as needed the next day.  Could abuse, but would run out of Rx way too early & then Dr. would cease Rx or I'd have to live w/ anxiety for most of month until next refill.  I don't want either & I don't want to fill sluggish so there's no temptation of abuse for me.  i just like feeling normal & looking normal in public.  Only down side is that I choose to wait 2 hrs. B4 driving just to be sure I don't have the odd adverse affect unexpectedly

column2: mr.smith, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've been taking this medication for 24 years now.  My first bout with panic disorder was in the military many years ago. They had no idea what I had, so I turned to alcohol (just for attacks).  When I returned to the USA, a doctor put me on Valium. Hated Valium.  Then came Xanax, and I was able to live again.  I was prescribed 2mg 3x a day which I took for a few years with absolutely no side affects at all. I read about it's addictivity, so I experimented myself and actually have taken myself off a few times, but the panic attacks resume within days. I have personally reduced my dosage between 3 to 4 mg per day and that seems to be the perfect combo for me. Never drowsy, eat well, sleep well and has allowed me to run a couple of successful businesses. I truly believe that there are certain drugs that completely take care of a problem with some people and do not do so with other. You have to find what works for you, simple as that. This medication has allowed me to live a normal life, be successful and even fly and drive cross country etc.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)

column2: happynow, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: When I was 50 years old I started having severe panic disorder which basically paralyzed me.  Any disruption of my regular schedule prompted an attack.  My doctor prescribed Xanax which immediately helped.  However, I was hospitalized with severe depression and the doctors there thought the Xanax was the cause so they "weaned" me off in a week's time.  After trying every antipressant known to man, I refused to take anything that made me feel like a zombie.  With counseling my depression was cured, but I started the panic attacks again and was again given Xanax.  It wasn't until I changed doctors in 1998 that I was offered Citalopram 20mg (to take at night because it made me sleepy), that I became like myself again.  I never laughed or had fun, but after about two weeks I realized that I was actually laughing out loud and just felt my brain was organized if you know what I mean. These two drugs together changed my life.  I have highs and lows and emotions, and feel 20 years younger.  For those who are scared of addiction, who cares if they help you and if you don't abuse them?  That's exactly what my doctor said.  I was feeling guilty of taking an addictive drug.So relax, find something that helps you and enjoy life.
