column9: I have suffered from anxiety /panic attacks most of my teenage adult life. I have been put on antidepressents,which is a joke,for me,my brain makes plenty of serotonin.Xanex is the only med that helps me.I take a light .o5 mlg. dose about every twelve hours,to keep it at a study amount in my system,which greatly reduces my anxiety,hyperness ,and balences me out,so i am not such a chronic worry wart.While on this ,it helps me not to dwell on stupid things that do not matter,not worry about unimportant things,or whatothers think,and enables me to concentrate on important things,along with making me more calm and relaxed.The stronger dose,the 1 mlg. is alot stronger, so if I really am in panic attack mode I will take 1 half or a full one if I am not planning on driving.This medicine is about the only thing that I have found to be effective for me,and has helped me so much.I do not feel it is addicting in any way.If more doctors would get over thier fears and treat people on a case by case basis and quit shoving antidepressants at people,and prescribe proven antianxiety meds like this to patients,we would see alot less heart attacks,and other stress related heart conditions,as well as alot less suicides,self medicating behaviors and the like.I have lupus and fibro,diabetes and premenstraul dismorphic disorder along with many health disorders as a result of the lupus and fibro,Keeping my anxiety and stress is key to keeping me healthy and reducing my flare ups.This is the only medicine that works for me.They need to keep it on the market and doctors who have stereotyped it or refuse to give it to certian patients who need it,to keep well like people like me,with stress related illnesses,should get in trouble.if taken correctly and not overdone or abused,this is a wonderful medication,I have nothing but good things to say,it has greatly improved my quality of life.The other things I have taken were a joke,this one works wonders!!!!

column9: My doc put me on 3mg a day for anxiety and panic attacks. I was also taking Effexor for depression. By the third year I was up to 8mg a day. It's a great drug but very addictive. A couple of docs told me the only way to get off was to ween off slowly over several months. Then my doc did some research and wanted to try something new. He stopped the Xanax & put me on a decreasing dose of Klonopin for a week then put me on Depakote, Neurontin, and Seroquel. I gained over 40 lbs. in less than 2 months. The withdrawls were nothing like stopping cold turkey but the other meds aren't helping with the anxiety. So now I have to ween off these and deal with a weight issue that depresses me even more. I think I'm worse off than when I was taking Xanax. If anyone has any suggestions I would love to hear them. Email me at ms_molases@yahoo.com

column2: trnitup, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on alprazolam for ten years.It gave me my life back.The anxiety attacks I used to experience were debilitating.3mg per day.No more than that,but sometimes only 2mg.My thinking is actually clearer on this med than it was before because an anxiety attack would send my mind racing and unable to concentrate or focus.Not to mention the fact that I would get clammy hands,heart palpitations,severe chest pains and more making me think I was having a heart attack.When I started this medicine it all stopped completely.Now I feel absolutely normal and am not afraid to leave my house for fear of another attack like I used to get many times a week.Anxiety can cause you to become agoraphobic from fear of having another attack while away from your comfort zone like your own house.But yes,,it is addictive for sure,so if at any point in the future anyone that needs to stop taking this MUST taper off at a Very slow rate [like several weeks] or you will have very severe withdrawal symtoms which I understand is EXTREMELY unpleasant,also possible seizures and even death.I have no plans to stop because of it's effectivness for me.Buspar,Effexor,Paxil,Welbutrin,and all those types of drugs left me feeling unable to experience any natural highs or lows,somewhat like an automaton or a zombie.Alprazolam does not do that,that is why I like it.No,,it does not get me feeling buzzed except in the very initial stages of first use.I feel nothing from it now,just normal with no weird side effects and no anxiety.I hope this might help some of you out there with your quest to feel better and hopefully normal once again.

column2: aa, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
dmy38, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been taking xanax for 20 years now.  I am 38 and started having social anxiety disorder in 8th grade along with panic attacks, migraines, muscle tension and depression.  I suffered with that until I was 20 as the doctor I was seeing during my childhood told me it was all in my imagination and there was nothing he could do for me.  I decided it was time to see another doctor.  I have tried just about every medication out there for social anxiety disorder and xanax is the only one that has worked for me. It allowed me to live a normal life and function in society again. I have to take it every day as I have constant anxiety.  I do best on .5mg-1mg per day but I have gone down to .25mg per day now as I am trying to get pregnant and I will need to be completely off of the xanax during my pregnancy and for breastfeeding afterwards.  I am however very scared of coming off of the xanax.  I have been on it for so long and if I am not physically addicted to it, then I am definitely mentally addicted to it. Xanax saved my life.  I have always been aware that it is highly addictive and never allowed myself to take more than 1 mg per day and my body was fine with that.  I never needed any more than that, thank god!  I just hope now that I can ween myself off of the .25 mg without horrible withdrawals.  Like everyone else has stated, this drug is HIGHLY addictive and if you dont have severe anxiety/depression, try other drugs first to see if they work because once you are on xanax, you are going to suffer some withdrawals if you decide to come off of it.  I dont regret taking xanax and it is what works best for me but I wish they would develop something that works likes xanax but that is not addictive. I would recommend xanax ONLY if you have constant SEVERE anxiety, social anxiety and constant panic attacks as I did.  Dont give up though!  Keep searching for what works best for you as there are so many options out there.

column2: Jperryprincess, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been reading the troubles everyone is having with this medicine and don't understand it. I have Panic disorder, anxiety and Post traumatic Stress syndrome plus Epilipsy. The Dr's have tried every drug in the xanax catagory, kyloonipin, ativan and valiums and xanax has worked the best. I have been on and off of it for years. I was allowed 3 1mg tabs a day as needed, even with feeling a seizure coming on. I have reached that amount maybe 5 times. It helps for many reasons, lesser chance of addiction, more chance that it's going to work and it responds faster when it is given as needed. It's been a godsend to me when stressful situations leave me fighting the 'ora' of having an epileptic seizure. When nightmares drag me back to where I was in danger, it does help. It helps me so much that I don't need it 3 times a day let along adding more and bumping it up. Epilepsy came to me at a young age due to a stroke. I gave up drinking while young friends were partying. I'm not worried about mixing them. If you are taking this medicine, it isn't worth having that drink, your anxiety will only get worse or you will wind up where you don't want to be. the only bad thing about xanax if you don't let yourself abuse it is it tastes NASTY. BUT it is soooooo worth it to take the bitter taste for a moment and continue with life. it isn't a miracle drug, but it helps me to know when I need it to keep me fron getting hurt during a seizure or keep my anxiety under control, it's there ready to help me thru it. bless the inventor

column9: I was encouraged to stop taking it at my own request because I had heard of how hard it was to quit.  It was THE ONE MOST DIFFICULT THING I HAVE EVER DONE.  Finally, after probably a year or more of feeling horrible, panicking day after day, quitting and restarting, I broke the habit. I was attending a Group Rehab meeting and believe me, it was horrible.  I felt great after I was finally off it, but I really did a great bit of work with a Psycho Therapist, who came to my home, because I was too panicky to drive to hers. column2: badabing28, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
jm xanax expert, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Xanax has been a panacea for anxiety. Nothing else I have used compares. The only drawback is the short half-life, and weaning off it after extensive periods of use. Anxiety heightens, emotions are haywire, fear is ever-present. You feel as if all eyes are on you. The drug of course relieves all of this and I have led a normal life on it for years. If you take more than prescribed, beware of the tolerance and eventual dependance. Doctors and pharmacists are not the enemy (as they seem if you are withdrawing)but they know the addictive potential and are very careful when prescribing. I have weaned myself to 2 1/2 0.5mg tabs daily from a high of 6mg (or 12 0.5) a day, and it was not fun. Weaning takes a long time and should never be done without a plan or you could have a seizure. Overall my experiences using the drig as prescribed have been very positive, and I am back to a slightly lower dose now. The best use is "as needed" as it avoidss tolerance and addiction, and you will not run out. No weird side-effects. Peace and tranquility that were never part of my life are possible now. Do not mix with opiods as that will land you in rehab before you know it. I was also addicted to various prescription pain meds which are no longer part of my life (thank God, but I miss them at times!). Good luck to those who use this drug as it can really be beneficial for anxiety and panic attacks.

column2: Elliott, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had taken xanax for approximately 4 years, I think it works great.  During the time that I took it, I had no problems.  Then I had an experience when I blacked out, completely and became very aggressive, but do not remember anything that happened that night.  Over the duration of that night, I had two shots of hot dam.  The combination fo the two caused this blackout.  I had been ordered to quit taking my xanax immediately.  So I stopped taking it.  I went thru withdrawls for several weeks, severe shaking, nausa, paranoia.  Now that I have been off of them for about 10 1/2 months, I feel like they have done some severe damage to my brain.  I forget things, I cannot remember things that I have asked people, nor things that I may have done.  But during the time that I was taking them, I thought everything was fine.  But now, my husband will ask me about something that we may have discussed, or maybe something that we watched on TV, or anything during that 4 years that I took xanax.  I cannot remember much about anything during that period.  It is as if I was living in a fog.  The xanax was a cover up for me to hide behind to deal with issues that arise with my husband, and kids, I would just pop another xanax, and hide behind it.  Although I have had these severe reactions since I quit taking it, I still think that it works well to treat severe depression, and anxiety.

column9: This drug is a miricle! I would have uncontrolable panic attacks at all times of the day and night with no known trigger. These started when I was 17 years old, and now I am 27. Which was what I was doing when I was younger and had no idea what was going on. My Dr has tried to put me on numerous antidepressants and take away the xanax. I noticed none of those worked, maybe I didn't want them too, maybe they didn't target what the problem really is. I'm not depressed, I just get scared. So I would always go back to the Xanax. Though the initial effects are severe sleepiness and and listlessness, I notice the calming, tranquil effects last for a couple days to follow. Nothing really bothers me. I say I take about 2mg in a week to two weeks. Never at the same time, and never in with the same time gap. I love to thave the fall back, because when it was happening EVERY DAY and would last for HOURS AND HOURS my life was hell. column2: BostonSun, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: My condition is a combination of chronic (constant) anxiety, acute panic disorder, and chronic insomnia. I have a very high-pressure job in the technology field. My brain does NOT shut off. I had not slept more than three hours in a row since I was 14 years old. I am a survivor of a violent rape attack. For decades, I worried constantly and massive panic would paralyze me randomly (mostly at night). The emotional and physical symptoms (desperate thoughts, racing mind, pounding heartbeat, shaking, sweating, severe nausea) would make me think I was dying or going insane. It was imperative that I got HOME and turn on all the lights and create background noise. It was a nightmare to live like this.  Many doctors over twenty-five years prescribing countless ineffective medications only made me feel more hopeless.  Xanax has been a godsend to me.  I take one 1MG Xanax at night (as needed, only occasionally now) before bed (usually around 11:00) and in twenty minutes I am sound asleep. When I wake up in the morning (usually 5:30) I am relaxed. No longer are fear, worry, and panic my first thoughts of the day.  I experience very few side effects (a bit of clumsiness) but I can laugh at myself and am more tolerant of my own shortcomings.  If panic creeps up on me during the day/evening, I can calm myself knowing that when I get home, I will sleep - and things will be better in the morning.  It also helps knowing I have my Xanax with me in my purse at all times, and if I needed to take one, I can. I am not worried about addiction or increased dosage. My doctor (for the past four years) has monitored me closely, and my 1MG Xanax dosage is working well.  I am very grateful for it. Life, with all its challenges, is liveable now.

column9: I have been on this Medication (Alprazaloam) for over 15 years.  I have to say it got me through the worst times of my life.  I have never taken more than quarter of a pill (.5mg)  in one day,  sometimes don't need them at all, but do suffer with panic disorder.I also suffer with Claustrophobia, which is as bad as panic diorder, when the two are combined it is no picnic.  I can say this Medication has helped me get through some very horrible episodes .  However, if I had it to do over again would not take it again.  I do believe it is very addictive.  I for one would like to get off this medication ,but fear the other problems will multiply for me,  so which is worse.  Addicted to a  1/4 of a pill when needed or sufferening with Panic Attacks that make you feel like your going to die and Claustraphobia that is so intense you want to die.  People that have never suffered from this conditions do not understand the complexity of them.  I am 73 years old and right now the last thing I need is seizures etc.  had my share of the severe panic attacks that make you feel like you are going to die with rapid heart beat, sweating etc.  Maybe I should get off this medication while I can.  Does any one have any suggestions?  I am open to finding out the best way to detach yourself from this medication.  I do know my panic/anxiety,claustraphobia are kept in control when I have to take that little quarter of a pill.  I do not take the recommended dosage, which is 3 times a day.  Never had to do that.  Its just a relief to know if you feel an attach coming you have something that you know helps you through it.  Not fun having these attacks.

column2: PleaseBeCareful, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Xanax is a double-edged sword. It works very effectively but it also is habit forming. I have been on this medication for about 8 years and frankly, I can not function without it. It keeps my temper in check and allows me to focus. One side effect that I don't like is that it causes me some memory problems. People have told me things while I am on this drug and I swear I do not recall being spoken to. Aditionally, I have panic attacks and this medication is a life saver ! Although the pills are extremely bitter, when having a panic attack holding one under my tougne allows the medication to absorb quickly and bring me back down. Please use extreme caution while using this medication and do not double doeses ... in fact, I split pills and take 1/2 the recommended dose @ a time and then supplement about an hour later. The drowsiness can be a real pain so spacing out the dosages helps me to keep alert. DO NOT mix with booze or pain medication !!!!! I accidentially chose to drink after a stressful day @ the office ( forgetting I had taken several Xanax's ) and I had a full blown black-out and do not recall anything from that night past the first drink. Thankfully, I was with family & friends that recognized what had occured and got me safely home. PLEASE, I can not stress this enough ... Be VERY careful with this medication, follow Dr's orders and DO NOT abruptly stop taking this medication if you have used it long term. The withdrawl effect for me are awful. Peace.

column2: Rowan, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: The ONLY benzo that works for me, and I have taken them all. Been on this drug for 20 years. Very fast working, can actually stop a panic attack from getting worse if taken when attack starts. NO side effects for me. After 20 years, on 4 mg per day, 1 mg 4 times a day. To CB, any good doctor is going to hesitate writing you a prescription for this drug. This drug is dangerous as you can overdose easily, and, even worse, getting off it takes months. After being on it 20 years, we anticipate it will take 8 months to a year for me to get off it. But since I have had this condition for so long, and it is the only thing that helps, I will probably be taking it until the day I die. It is the only reason I am alive today. Before this drug, I was suicidal. I had over 20 doctors tell me my "spells" were because I was nervous over something or other. The hardest part is to get a doctor to listen to you and understand what you are going through. The only ones that seem to do this are phychiatrists. Forget MDs and Interns. They don't get it at all.

column9: Back in April of 2000(I was 22yrs old) My dr started giving me Xanax.  It was the worst drug anyone could ask for!  If you are taking this, STOP! Go see a new dr and ask about other drugs, Klonopin, Ativan etc. Xanax is EXTREMELY addictive and you will probably get terrible headaches on 1 side of your brain, almost like someone is squeezing your brain until you take a Xanax.  It has the same effect on your heart, you may feel as if it's in a Vice being crushed! That's the withdrawals and signs of addiction and dependency.  I would not wish this drug on my worst enemy.  A dr attempted to give this drug to my 22yr old girlfriend.  I was so disgusted that he would start a young, healthy female on SUCH a strong and drastic medication.  She had NO business taking Xanax.  She took Lexapro and did just fine.  Ask other people that ARE'NT still taking this "sh*t" as it's called and I'm quite certain they will agree, Xanax is BAD NEWS! I only hope to warn you, I was addicted to this crap for 3 years.  It was NOT fun or pretty coming off the sh*t! M. in Cali.

column2: txrhandic, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started having anxiety attacks in February. One night the ambulance was called as my breathing caused me to pass out. A little oxygen, and I was fine. Two nights later I was in the ER with chest pain. I knew I was dying. I am 22 years old and was admitted in front of the 50 or so people there because they thought I might be having heart problems. EKG showed normal. Chest x-rays showed normal. Pain in my rib area, tightness and pressure on my chest and shoulders, and irregular breathing and heart beats. My blood pressure was 98/68 and my pulse was 140. The doctor gave me a Xanax .5 mg and my problems were solved. (At least until I could be given something else.) He prescribed me Lexapro with Xanax and the Lexapro didn't work. I was to take the Xanax 3 times daily, but instead just took it as needed with the attacks, and in no time, they were under control. Was then placed on Zoloft, and given Xanax (again, to take every 8 hours, but I still only take as needed) and life has become great again. Zoloft is taken between 8 and 9 PM and Xanax if needed (sometimes for sleep, too) and my life ROCKS! My husband says he can finally stand me again, and my mom (who lives 2 states away) says she no longer worries about me at night. It is my miracle drug. I will never go above .5 mg however, because I know plenty of strung out people who got that way from Xanax bars. I would recommend it to anyone with serious anxiety attacks. I was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder.

column2: SiliconeAndStars, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have used xanax for about a year and a half to treat my anxiety.  It works fast and I no longer notice any side effects from it.  Initially it made me tired but now I don't even notice.  It is habit forming but as long as the person taking it does not abuse it, then there should be no problem.  Definitely do not drink alcohol with it because it increases the effects of alcohol and drinking while taking it can actually cause death.  I made the mistake once of thinking it was out of my system and had a shot... big mistake.  I felt quite intoxicated from 1 shot.  My anxiety has been worse lately and so I am considering going on a daily medication for axiety (the xanax is as needed only) and my Dr. prescibed Paxil but I have yet to take it.  I have read reviews about it, and quite honestly... it almost scares me.  From what I've read, it doesn't seem to work as well for people in my age group (19-24) If anyone else is taking paxil and in my age group... please send me an email if you can and tell me how paxil has worked for you. column9: i have had panic anxiety and agrophobia since i was 21 i am now 28 for the first 4 yrs of me having these episodes i was not able to even leave my house i had to have my wife my mom and my sister just to go see a doctor i have seen alot of diffrent doctors since then i was put on every antidepressent there was and had alot of bad experiences with almost all of them about 3 yrs ago i was seeing a new doctor who perscribed me xanax 1mg 3x a day and catapress within the first week of me being on this new treatment i was almost back to my normal self almost anyway i felt like a huge bolder was taken off my back i gave this med a 3 star for satisfaction cause alot of ppl abuse this drug so its really hard to find a doctor who dosent see u as just a drug seeker and as a person who really needs help i know i will be on this med for probly my whole life since there is no real cure for panic disorder all there is is just controlling it so it doesnt control u anyway this drug is great for ppl like me who truely need it i know its addictive but that is not a big deal for someone like me i wouldnt even have a life if not for this drug and trearments so unless  u have to take it dont pls for ppl like me who need it just to live a normal life

column2: Jenerationx, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I take this for Hereditary Essential Tremor which is combined with myoclonic seizures and dystonia (all part of one hereditary disorder). It also helps the panic attacks and anxiety that I have. I was taking 2mg/day for 10 yrs and recently went up to 3 mg as needed which I take maybe 2-3x a wk. *Note: I have a high tolerance for meds: I'm 5'4 and 140 lbs and I take 1 mg in the morning and 1 in the afternoon with no problem and it's always been that way. My 6'4" 195 lbs boyfriend had to take 1mg for insomnia and fell asleep for 16 hrs.*The amount you take will depend on your tolerance and why you are taking it. If you are really uncomfortable with developing an addiction, keep in mind that you are under a doctor's care plus there may be another non-physically addictive drug you can try. This is a personal opinion and experience, but I find that the people who have become psychologically addicted a)use xanax as a  recreational drug and/or b)do not follow the prescribed directions. Respect xanax for what it is: a drug.  I find it really helps my tremors so I can write, type, speak a little better, feel less "jumpy". It also helps my anxiety so I don't become severely agoraphobic again.

column2: Mike, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Im 31 and have been living with Anxiety and Panic attacks since I was 19.  Ive tried the Wellbutrins and Zolofts over the years but the side effects were brutal.  I have a VERY stressful and high end/demanding sales job with many face to face meetings and presentations.  I almost lost my job because I would start having a panic attack in the middle of meetings.  My DR. gave me a RX for .25's a few years ago. I took them and they helped, but stopped because everyone told me I would get dependent on them.  DONT listen to other people, everyone is different and everyone has different tolerances and addictive personalities.  This is the ONLY RX ive tried that doesn't make you feel "drugged" and you can actually function normally.  Ive never felt like ive been addicted to them and it is comforting to know I have them when I need them.  Point blank they work, dont increase your own dosage and dont drink with them...if you get anxiety attacks or panic attacks, and you feel like you cant even walk into a restraurant, Xanax can help you....and they work quick and last a good amount of time. I believe people who get addicted to them increase there own dosage or abuse them. If you think they have stopped working, unless your a DR., go see one!! If your DR. was understanding enough to prescribe them to you, he/she will listen and help.  I hope this has helped others out there with the horrible disease...most of all never give up and think positive. Your not alone, there are more of us out there than you think!!!

Until I filed a police report and gave it to my dr. did I get a refill.  I finally found a great physican that see this as a problem. 2 mg a day is to much for my age, 57.  This really scared the bejesus out of me.  I'm now in the process of cutting down "slowly" to .5 as needed.  I'm taking .75 per day now and cannot wait until I can control this med instead of it controlling me.  I don't recommend this med to anyone unless it is absolutely necessary and under a strict doctor's care.

column9: Xanax (Alprazolam) is an effective sedative for my transient anxiety.  I usually take this medication (0.5 mg) before board meetings and other public events where I am on point; sometimes I take it before getting on a plane, especially if I want to rest during flight. Otherwise, it's a very calming medication, but potentially habit-forming.

column2: cblpn2005, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My MD prescribed me 0.5mg initially, then increased the dosage to 1 mg when I lost a family member. As a way to cope with my loss, I highly abused the 1 mg dose (I went through 90 tablets in just over a week's time). The withdrawals from this was complete hell, as I went through major psychosis, mood changes left and right, and so on. I managed to make it through withdrawals on my own and with friends as my support system. I am now on 0.25 mg as needed, and feel much better. Xanax can be great for anxiety/panic attacks, but can also be highly addictive, physically and psychologically. Remember to use caution when taking it. I regret abusing it and using it as an excuse to cope with losing a loved one, but after the withdrawals, I no longer want to experience something like that again. Taking a low dose only when needed is working just fine for me now.

column2: citychick, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: After yrs. of severe panic/anxiety + 2 trips to the E.R., this is a godsend! I used to have severe panic & anxiety!! Thought I was dying of a heart attack or stroke! This is my lifesaver, and others, due to severe rage, to the point that I have wanted to physically hurt people, in fact have done so to my hubby. Have been on 3mg. X.R., because taking 1mg. 3x a day, left me feeling panic when it wore off! This has saved me! I am also taking Lamictal to help w/ the rage, also a great help! YES, your body does get addicted, I have been on it for 5 yrs.? Am seeing a psych., as my G.P. said she could not continue to write rx's. As far as bodily addiction, I ran out for 6 days, cause I couldn't get an appt. in time, I thought I was gonna die!! It was AWFUL!! Had to take massive pain pills from a friend to help calm me! Not much help! Should have gone to the E.R.!! Like I said, this has been a TOTAL godsend for me!! Just don't abuse! My psych. has me in every month, to refill. It does take effect very quick, which is great!! It does make me very sleepy, I am o.k. & work, but get zoned, & on days off, I do sleep way too much! I am going to ask my Dr. to put me back on wellbutrin, as I have heard great things about it, I just didn't give it enough time! All in all, this is the ONLY thing that that has helped w/ panic & anxiety!!!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Xanax is very effective for anxiety, however it is extremely addictive.  I read that some people were told by their doctors to use Klonopin with this drug when its effectiveness waned over time.  Do not add Klonopin as medication with Xanax because it, too, is extremely addictive.  And yes, Xanax dosage must be increased over time to be effective, but this is a mistake as well.  Xanax withdrawal can harm your central nervous system, can cause extreme anxiety much worse than the original anxiety, and can cause seizures when stopped.  Please listen.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Yeah, xanax works really well for anxiety and panic--it's a wonder drug. But, it's soooo addictive! Even if you don't have addiction issues, don't try it. It increases GABA in the brain, so if you take too many, you black out. Seriously, if you've got anxiety, panic, or trouble sleeping, there are alternatives to an addictive drug. Ok, off to a Narcotics Anonymous meeting I go because of this xanax stuff...

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This drug works extremely well for panic attacks, but it is VERY addictive.  If you have any addictive tendencies, I would not recommend. This has been the most difficult drug to withdrawal from--it took me 3 months to feel normal again.

column2: jpete1, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
masonbamace@yahoo.com,  Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Xanax is a very dependant drug. I have been on the 1mg tablet for about 10 yrs then went on to the 2mg twice a day and it seems that the 2mg last alot longer. But I would tell anyone if you dont have a problem with your nerves and dont need this drug to just leave it alone. Ive been hooked on lots of pills and xanax is one of the worst pills to run out of!! They say that you can run out of pain pills and it wont kill ya but if you run out of nerve meds it will and if you have ever been thru withdrawalls you know exactly what im saying but I guess I would have to say Im 30 yrs old now and been on them sence 15 yrs old I will probably never know life without xanax so again if you dont have to have them please thank God above you dont have to have em.Good luck to all and God-Bless

This seems to be the problem about taking Xanax, if you have ever had a panic attack you know that it feels like you're having a stroke, so when you feel like that and you take xanax, that's just it, panic attacks are over, shakey hands, all anxiety without reason is over, but from then on your life pretty much depends on this medication, trust me, it is the type of drug that you will know if you haven't taken in the last 10 hours or so. I know that i am addicted to life with xanax, but the trick here is not increase your dosage ever. the momment you do that then you're in big trouble (rehab problem). Take it only if no other treatment works to stop those panic attacks, if your attacks doesn't come everyday then don't take it everyday, take it only when you start to feel it coming. if you have any tendency to abusing or taking a little more than your supposed to. don't even start with xanax. it's all about controlling yourself, wether it's the panic attacks you have or the xanax addiction.

column2: Amanda29, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Xanax for about 5 years. The first time I ever had a panic attack I was at work and I started crying for no reason.  My boss had a xanax and she give me one. It helped me instantly. I went to the Dr. an he perscribed me .5 mg 4 times a day. I tried the dose he told me to take but that was a little much. So I take 1/2 of one 4 times a day. It seems to work well for me. But I have to admit they are very habit forming. If I don't take one afterthe last one I took wears off I get very nervous. When I am about out of meds I get really anxious to where I will get them from someone else that has some. These people that only think they need them once every week or so don't need them at all. I am very sensitive to ssri's like lexapro or effexor so I don't take nothing else to manage my nerves. If I had to do it all over again I would have never started taking xanax. I feel dizzy all the time and drowsy and hungry,thats why I have gained 20 lbs. I am mostly more nervous in the morning. My panic attacks have been so severe I have had ct scans done on my brain, all kinds of blood work to check my thyroid and thank God everything is normal. I think I am going to need help getting off of these pills. They make me feel sometimes like I am so irritable I take things out on my kids. So my advice is to never take them unless you really, really need them. Because they are very hard to get off of without some kind of intervention.

I will never take it again, not because it wasn't helpful, but because not having it suddenly was VERY VERY bad. Valium is MUCH better....not as harsh as Xanax.

column9: im an 18 yr old male and ive been taking 2 .5 milligram pills daily when needed for about a year now, but they are always both needed by the end of the day, they helped for alittle while, bringing me from my depressed moody anxiousness to a realxed and rarely loopy mood, lately however ive had to take two at a time to experiance the any relief, and one will simply do nothing when having one of these episodes, it really works when i feel an episode coming on(or during one) but now i require a larger dose and as i need at least 2 doses a day i cant take it as my pills are regulated by my parents, so i have to wait until my first episode of the day and judge whether its worth waiting until i feel worse, over all the drug works, but at the dose im prescribed(.5 milligram pills) 2 pills at a time,it has become immpossible to treat all of my episodes daily,in short they barely even help anymore, so i shall speak with my doctor about a possible alternative or at least a larger dose(1 milligram pills)i was givin two different depression meds before being swithced to just xanax as the depression meds worsened my condition,my docotr felt that the depression meds were just worsening my condition rather than helping, and that any other anti depressants would be a waste of time, so i hope i can continue to use it for my episodes, but they way it is seeming i will require a much larger dose, i was hoping to find an alternative, but my doctor has not been very succesful in finding me one that works, they believe a benzodiazapine is what i should be taking as my depression is based more on anxiety but dont feel they are in teh right to prescribe me anythiong stronger asdependance is very common and my needing it so often would only become an addiction if moved to something stronger, all in all it has been working, its just been working less and less

column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Xanax RX about 20 mlg for three months to alleviate symptoms of anxiety disorder. I took a time-released dose, which put a complete stop to my panic attacks but ravaged my ability to function proficiently. I experienced extreme short-term memory loss, to the point that I would forget what I was talking about in the middle of a sentence or where I was going when I drove to the grocery store. I started to decrease my dose with the intention of alleviating these negative side effects, and I realized I had become completely physically addicted. So I kicked Xanax cold turkey (though this is not recommended by any physician) and experienced nearly debilitating withdrawals; very painful migraines, inability to sleep, and increased panic attacks. I do not recommend this medication in any high dose, or on a daily basis. AWFUL.

column2: Waldmurmeltier, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: On Xanax since 1988. "Benzos" are said to work magically at first, and it's true...then tolerance for the med builds up, and you have to take more to get the same effect. I was recently shamed by a prescriber into titrating down from 3.5 mg per diem to 1.75. (Yes, there is a lot of stigma attached to taking this drug.) I made the transition OK, but there's no disputing that it is addictive. Every patient on this med long enough probably has to try to establish what percentage of its effect is attributable to satisfying the craving and what percentage is allocable to anxiety reduction, and then decide whether or not to seek an alternative therapy. I have tolerated Xanax well over these many years, though, and haven't found side-effects to be a problem.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was placed on Xanax .5mg x3 a day. It was a life saver! I took this medicine for about 5 years. No adverse side affects. I had lessened anxiety, panic attacks and mood swings. My family doctor however decided that he would no longer write prescriptions for Xanax anymore and cut me off cold turkey! I am retired from the emergency medical field, so I knew what was about to happen: Withdrawl. I had a Very Hard time finding a doctor that would write Xanax scripts. However I did find one and he keep me at my usual doseage and all was fine. Later on he prescribed Clonapin, it works almost as well as Xanax with no side affects. I no longer have to take Xanax or feel the need for one. Before if I would be away from home and remember that I forgot my Xanax I would start "Jonesing" for one, like the need for a cig. or something like that. Overall I think what I am trying to say about Xanax is: It is a great drug that does what it is supposed to do, however it is HIGHLY addictive. So just be careful with it. Clonapin helped get me off Xanax and works almost as good. I don't know why so many doctors are afraid to give Xanax, it's easy to know if the person is abuseing it. Doctors need to wake up! If your going to give it to someone for more than 2 weeks, you need to be prepared to make it a lifetime prescription or at least take it away when the person taking it says they no longer need it. Withdrawl from Xanax would have been hell if I hadn't found another doctor.

column2: whawkslady1@aol.com, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Xanax has been great for me.I've been on Xanax, not generic, since 1975.  Xanax is the only medicine of this type that has been a constant in my life.  I've been thru internal medicine, psychiatrists, psychologists, cardiologists, pain mgt., pulmonary docs etc.  I do not have a heart, pulmonary or psychiatry problem.  I do see my PCP, spine surgeon (for spinal fusion a few months ago),and a pain mgt doc. They all agree that Xanax is the best for me.  I've tried almost all the other meds but they do not work for me.  Within 1/2 hr. my heart rate and breathing comes back to normal and I can resume my normal life.  It took me 4 yrs., 3 hospitals' testing (I live in OH) and 7 docs to finally attest it is a chemical imbalance which causes the anxiety/panic attacks.  I don't think I will ever be taken off Xanax.  I never know when or where the attacks will come.  The docs have explained that the adrenaline in my brain gushes out in spurts rather than evenly.  My heart rate was 165, couldn't breathe, had to sit up to sleep a little and hands were fisted & numb when awakening.   Also, I do believe it might be hereditary because my Mother, Brother, Daughter and Son have had attacks but not as severe or constant as mine.  None have been prescribed medications so far, except my late Mother.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Symptoms: Heart palpitations, derealization, slowed thinking/cognitive ability, lightheaded, brain fog, memory loss, panic attacks, obsessive compulsive, and depression over the course of 2 months.  Within two days on Xanax I was 95% back to normal.  Makes me sleepy though.  Wonderful drug for me, I'm pretty much back to normal and happy again!

column9: I use Xanax for vertigo caused by Meniere's Disease.  It is fast acting w/no side effects for me, possibly because I have taken it for a long time.  I had already gone through all the other typical vertigo drugs when my Nurse Practioner prescribed it.

column2: love my xanex, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have taken Xanex for 23 years it is the only drug that helps my panic and anxiety, Dr's have had me try things like Paxil, Proxac etc; they made. they made me crazy. I take 3 mg a day no more sometimes less. But i did have to learn about how addicting this drug is, my husband picks it up from the pharmacy and hides it and gives it to me as prescribed. Use caution and do not go cold turkey if you decide to go off this drug, it will make you feel like you are dying.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Xanax gave me my life back.  I function very well on it with no side effects.  I've taken it off and on for many years now, and have been able to overcome severe agorophobia.  I take a low maintenance dose (.25 mg per day, split into two doses) that enables me to adjust it according to my stressors of the day.  Due to the low dose, I do experience a few break-thru panic attacks, but they aren't as severe and respond quickly to another half pill (.125 mgs).  The low dose keeps me functioning normally, while also keeping me from the side effects and withdrawal symptoms that I've heard about, but never personally experienced while taking this drug. It works for me.
